description:
Terms that are not specific to Unani medicine,
used in Unani medicine literature

Science which deals with the movement of
celestial bodies

Faculty perceiving self-evident things and
meanings,independent of matter in its existence
and function, through which mind perceives
self-evident things and meanings in their
complete sense

Soul which coordinates rational functions of the
human; this term does not cover Nafs Nāṭiqa
mentioned under factors of existence

This term does not cover Ḥarakat mentioned
under factors of existence

A type of movement accompanied by change in
place of body or object, partially or totally

A type of movement accompanied by a change
in position of body or object, but without
changing its place

A type of movement accompanied by a change
in quantity of body or object

A type of movement accompanied by qualitative
change in body or object

Kingdoms of nature found as plants, animals
and minerals

An imaginary line which passes from east to
west and divides globe into equal north and
south hemispheres

An imaginary celestial circle which lies on same
plane as equator of the earth; the day and night
become equal when sun comes across
this plane

An imaginary illustration of celestial orbit divided
into twelve divisions

english_term:
school of thought
supporting experience
as the basis of
knowledge/empiricist
description:
One of three schools of thought having
difference of opinion on the method of obtaining
useful things for health, stating that such things
are acquired through experience

english_term:
school of thought
supporting assumption
and syllogism as basis
of knowledge
description:
One of three schools of thought having
difference of opinion on method of obtaining
useful things for health, stating that experience
alone is not sufficient and must be combined
with syllogism to obtain such things

english_term:
school of thought not
supporting views of
Aṣḥāb al-Tajriba and
Aṣḥāb al-Qiyās
description:
One of three schools of thought having
difference of opinion on method of obtaining
useful things for health, summarizing science of
medicine through manipulations by removing
topics with which Aṣḥāb al-Tajriba and Aṣḥāb
al-Qiyās preoccupied themselves and were
irrelevant in its opinion

Science by which one learns various states of
human body, in health and when not in health,
and means by which health is likely to be lost,
and when lost, is likely to be restored (science
of medicine/ Unani System of Medicine/
Unani Medicine)

Aspect of medicine concerned with theoretical
topics such as temperaments, humours,
faculties, various diseases, symptoms
and causes

Aspect of medicine concerned with knowledge
of medical management and practice, e.g.,
knowledge of methods of preserving health
under various conditions and treating every
kind of disease

Subject of medicine, which is the human body in
health and disease and as a whole deals with
primary components/elements, humours,
temperaments, simple and compound organs,
pneuma, faculties and their functions; states of
body with regard to health, disease and
intermediate state and causes thereof such as
air, food and drinks, water, habitation and
residence, physical and mental movement and
repose, sleep and wakefulness, elimination and
retention, occupation, age, gender and extrinsic
factors which act on body; preservation of health
and treatment of all the various diseases along
with dietary habits, purification and preservation
of air, regulation of rest and activity, use of drugs
and operative procedures

english_term:
causes / means of
health and disease

description:
One of four groups of causes of health and
disease whose immediate subject is organs and
their pneuma; the more remote subject is
humours; and the most remote subject is the
primary components / elements

One of four groups of causes of health and
disease which either preserve or produce
changes in the human body and are: (a) various
types of airs and associated factors; (b) food,
water and other drinks, etc.; (c) evacuation and
retention; (d) habitat and residence, etc.;
(e) physiological and psychological rest and
activity; (f) sleep and wakefulness; (g) various
phases of life and variations therein; (h) sex
variations; (i) occupations; (j) habits; and
(k) favourable and unfavourable agents
affecting the human body by contact

english_term:
formal causes / causes
related to form
description:
One of four groups of causes of health and
disease which include temperaments, facul-
ties emerging from these temperaments,
and structures

One of four groups of causes of health and
diseases which include functions

Reasonable thinking; tool to discover the
unknown from the known, which saves the
human being from errors in thinking

The process of knowing one reality on the basis
of reflection or expression of another factor or
knowledge of another reality, leading to
conclusive facts, e.g., yellowness of the face of
a person denotes fear, where one reality is face
and the other reality is the yellow expression
leading to fact, which is fear

Use of a statement in the complete meaning of
the subject of declaration, e.g., when a person
says that he saw the sun, he means to say that
he saw the complete disc of the sun

Use of a statement in part of the meaning of the
subject of the declaration, e.g., when one says
that he saw the sun intending that he saw part
of the disc of the sun at sunset time or intending
that he saw the sunlight or usage of the
expression in other than the meaning of its
subject, e.g., when one says that he saw the
lion, intending to mean that he saw a brave man

A statement about an object or phenomenon
which has many members and is applied to all
of them, e.g., human, which has many members
and the statement human includes all of them

Group of members similar in essence; a type of
universal concept, which covers all of its
members who are similar in their essence, e.g.,
human, whose members are Zaid, Mohan,
Jacob, etc.; they may differ in height, colour, etc.
but are one in reality

english_term:
(1) members or units of
a class having common
characteristics and
being divisible into
subordinate
kinds; (2) gender
description:
(1) A type of universal concept where members
or units of a class vary in their reality and the
variation is the part of reality of members, e.g.,
animal whose members are animals along with
humans;they differ in their reality but being an
animal is part of all of these diverse realities; (2)
either of two main divisions (male and female) of
humans and many of living organisms

english_term:
(1) distinguishing
character of a
group; (2) season
description:
(1) A type of universal concept having members
similar in reality and this similarity is part of the
reality of its members, e.g., being rational is part
of the reality of human and members of
humanity are similar in reality; (2) singular of
Al-Fuṣūl and means any one of four seasons
(Al-Fuṣūl al-Arba‘a) of the year (spring, autumn,
summer and winter); this term does not cover
Al-Fuṣūl al-Arba‘a mentioned under preservation
and promotion of health

A type of universal concept that is special for
one reality and is outside of its main essence,
e.g., laughing which is special for human but is
not part of its reality and essence

A type of universal concept that is not special for
one reality and is outside of its main essence,
e.g., walking which includes realities
other than human

Statement having one meaning, which is
applied to only a particular member
Affirmation that helps to ascertain unknown facts

english_term:
deduction of the state of
universal concept from
the state of divisive
concepts
description:
Reaching a conclusion regarding the state of
universal concept from the state of divisive
concepts; the conclusion will have specific
feature in its universal concept, e.g., conclusion
regarding the growth of the human being, while
seeing the members of the human growing in a
gradual manner

Deduction of the state of divisive concept from a
state of universal concept, i.e., reaching a
conclusion regarding the state of divisive
concept from the state of universal concept,
e.g., concluding that John, a divisive concept of
the human, is a rational animal because the
human is a rational animal

english_term:
deduction of the state of
other divisive concepts
from a state of the
divisive concept
description:
Reaching a conclusion regarding the state of
the divisive concept through the state of other
divisive concepts, e.g., concluding that cannabis
is illegal due to its similarity with liquor which is
also illegal

Statement expressing an opinion; may be true
or false and may be confirmed or rejected

Difference in two propositions where the truth of
one of the two requires the falsehood
of the other

(1) Thing that does not exist on its own and
depends on other things for its existence, e.g.,
colour; (2) An abnormal condition which appears
due to any other disease, e.g., headache
occurring due to fever

english_term:
(1) thing existing on its
own; (2) active
parts of drug
description:
(1) Thing that exists on its own and does not
depend on any other thing for its existence, e.g.,
body; (2) Part of the drug obtained through
specific processing methods which is
comparatively more active than its other parts;
(1) does not cover Jawāhir/Jawhara mentioned
under Unani pharmacology

Substance/material which acquires various
forms and cannot exhibit itself without them

Divisible thing(s); things divisible into length,
width and depth
Matter that can take any shape or form

The determinate structure which gives things
their essential characteristics

Form of a body which accepts the length,
width and depth

Form common to various objects of a specific
group that differentiates it from other groups

Seven factors considered to be essential for the
composition of the human body, which are
responsible for its existence, i.e., primary
components/elements, temperament, humours,
organs, pneuma, faculties and functions

Simple bodies that cannot be subdivided into
bodies having different forms and are primary
substances of human and non-human bodies,
producing different forms in nature through their
intermixture. (“Al-Arkān” has also been
translated as “elements” by many writers.
However, in the context of Unani medicine, this
is not taken as the elements of the periodic
table, rather for primary components, i.e., fire,
air, earth and water)
transliteration:
Al-Arkān / Ajsām Basīṭa/
Ajzā’ Awwaliyya/
Usṭuqussāt / ‘Anāṣir

description:
Primary components of human and non-human
bodies, i.e., fire, air, earth and water, producing
different forms in nature through their
intermixture

One of the four primary components /elements
of human and non-human bodies having cold
and dry quality, which remains situated at the
centre of all existence, make the objects firm
and stable, and maintain their forms and figures

One of the four primary components /elements
of human and non-human bodies having cold
and moist quality, which surrounds the earth and
lend itself readily to dispersion, and
consequently assumes any shape without
permanency, providing the possibility of things
being constructed, moulded, spread out and
attempered

One of the four primary components/elements of
human and non-human bodies having hot and
moist quality, which remains positioned above
the sphere of water and beneath that of fire and
rarefies and render things finer, lighter, more
delicate, softer and consequently better able to
move to the higher spheres

One of the four primary components /elements
of human and non-human bodies having hot
and dry quality, which remains positioned above
the other three primary components and
produces maturation, lightness and intermingling

Uniform quality of a compound present in its all
particles in equal proportion, developed due to
the interaction of opposite qualities of the four
primary components in such a manner that most
of the particles of each of the primary
components/elements may come into contact
with most of the others

Temperament wherein the opposite qualities
and quantities of all the participating primary
components/ elements in a compound are equal

Temperament wherein the qualities and
quantities of all the participating primary
components in a compound are not equal but
perfectly balanced as per the required
properties and functions of that compound
transliteration:
Mizāj Mu‘tadil Ṭibbī /
Mizāj
Mu‘tadil/‘Adl fi’l Qisma
native_term:
جازم / یبط لدتعم جازم
ف
ۃمسقلا � لدع /لدتعم

english_term:
equable temperament
of one species as
compared to other
species
description:
Particular temperament provided to a particular
species which is normal and most suitable for
that species but abnormal for other species
transliteration:
Mizāj Mu‘tadil Naw‘ī bi’l
Qiyās ila’l Khārij
native_term:
سایقلاب یعون لدتعم جازم
جراخلا یلا

english_term:
equable temperament of
a member of one
species as compared to
other members of the
same species
description:
Equable temperament provided to a member of
a species which is most suitable and best
among all the members of that species and has
not been provided to any other member of
that species
transliteration:
Mizāj Mu‘tadil Naw‘ī bi’l
Qiyās ila’l Dākhil
native_term:
سایقلاب یعون لدتعم جازم
لخادلا یلا

english_term:
equable temperament of
one race as compared
to other races
description:
Equable temperament provided to each race of
human species, which helps to perform the
required functions of each race with maximum
completeness
transliteration:
Mizāj Mu‘tadil Ṣinfī bi’l
Qiyās ila’l Khārij
native_term:
سایقلاب یفنص لدتعم جازم
جراخلا یلا

english_term:
equable temperament of
a person of one race as
compared to other
persons of the same
race
description:
Equable temperament provided to a person of a
race which is not provided to any other person
of that race and is better than all the persons
of that race
transliteration:
Mizāj Mu‘tadil Ṣinfī bi’l
Qiyās ila’l Dākhil
native_term:
سایقلاب یفنص لدتعم جازم
لخادلا یلا

english_term:
equable temperament of
a person as compared
to other persons
description:
Equable temperament provided to a person
which is most suitable for himself to perform his
normal functions but is not suitable for any
other person
transliteration:
Mizāj Mu‘tadil Shakhṣī
bi’l Qiyās ila’l Khārij
native_term:
یصخش لدتعم جازم
جراخلا یلا سایقلاب

english_term:
equable temperament of
a person as compared
to his own temperament
in different states
description:
Equable temperament provided to a person
which is most suitable for a particular period or
state in his life
transliteration:
Mizāj Mu‘tadil Shakhṣī
bi’l Qiyās ila’l Dākhil
native_term:
یصخش لدتعم جازم
لخادلا یلا سایقلاب

english_term:
equable temperament of
an organ as compared
to other organs
of the body
description:
Equable temperament furnished to each and
every organ of the body
transliteration:
Mizāj Mu‘tadil ‘Uḍwī bi’l
Qiyās ila’l Khārij
native_term:
یوضع لدتعم جازم
جراخلا یلا سایقلاب

english_term:
equable temperament of
an organ as compared
to its own temperament
in different states
description:
Equable particular temperament provided to an
organ in most suitable states which is most ideal
as compared to all other states of that organ
transliteration:
Mizāj Mu‘tadil ‘Uḍwī bi’l
Qiyās ila’l Dākhil
native_term:
یوضع ل دتعم جازم
لخادلا یلا سایقلاب

english_term:
abnormal temperament/
inequable temperament/
intemperament/
immoderate
temperament
description:
Temperament wherein the qualities and
quantities of all the participating primary
components in a compound are not in
accordance with the natural needs

Imbalanced temperament occurring due to
dominance of any one of the four qualities, i.e.,
hotness, coldness, dryness, moistness, over
the other three qualities

Imbalanced temperament occurring due to
dominance of two of the four qualities, i.e.,
hotness, coldness, dryness, moistness

Primary fluid of the body which is an initial
product of digestion and transformation of food

Four primary fluids of the body, i.e., sanguine,
phlegm, yellow bile and black bile

One of the four humours, which is characterized
by hot and moist temperament, red colour,
sweet taste and no odour; it is the best of all the
four varieties of humours

Red-coloured, odourless and sweet in taste
sanguine humour
transliteration:
Dam Ṭabī‘ī / Khūn
Ṭabī‘ī/ Dam Maḥmūd

description:
Sanguine humour, devoid of its normal qualities
either through change of temperament, such as
getting hot or cold, or due to admixture with the
humours derived from outside or produced
within the sanguine humour, e.g., when a part of
it gets putrefied, the lighter portion is converted
into abnormal yellow bile and the heavier portion
into abnormal black bile
transliteration:
Dam Ghayr Ṭabī‘ī /
Ghayr Ṭabī‘ī Khūn

description:
One of the four humours, which is white in
colour, bears cold and moist temperament and
is next to sanguine humour in excellence

Phlegm that can be converted into sanguine
humour by the body when needed

Phlegm devoid of basic characters of
normal phlegm

One of the abnormal types of phlegm, which is
saline or alkaline in taste and inclined towards
hotness and dryness

One of the abnormal types of phlegm, which is
sour in taste and inclined towards coldness
and dryness

One of the abnormal types of phlegm, which is
tasteless, very immature and quite cold

One of the abnormal types of phlegm, which is
gallic in taste and inclined towards coldness
and dryness

One of the abnormal types of phlegm, which is
sweet in taste and inclined towards hotness
and moistness

One of the abnormal types of phlegm, having
watery consistency

One of the abnormal types of phlegm, having
thicker consistency

One of the abnormal types of phlegm, having
mucoid consistency

One of the abnormal types of phlegm, having
vitreous consistency

One of the abnormal types of phlegm, having a
foul smell, produced by sepsis/infection/
putrefaction

english_term:
bile / yellow bile/
yellow humour/
bilious humour
description:
One of the four humours, which is yellow in
colour, has hot and dry temperament and is
next to phlegm in excellence

Yellow bile that remains like the froth in
sanguine humour, is yellowish red in colour, light
in weight and hot in temperament

Yellow bile that becomes abnormal either due to
addition of extraneous material or alteration in
its own composition

One of the abnormal types of yellow bile,
produced by the admixture of thick phlegm

One of the abnormal types of yellow bile,
produced by the admixture of thin phlegm

One of the abnormal types of yellow bile,
produced by the admixture of burnt black bile

One of the abnormal types of yellow bile,
produced by the combustion of ordinary yellow
bile, resulting in development of leek green
colour due to mixing of the burnt material with
the original yellow bile

The hottest and the most harmful of all
abnormal types of yellow bile, produced due to
extreme combustion of leek green bile

english_term:
black bile / black humour /
melancholic humour
description:
One of the four humours, which is black in
colour and has cold and dry temperament
transliteration:
Sawdā’ / Khilṭ Sawdā’/
Khilṭ Sawdāwī/ Mirra
Sawdā’/ Al-
Khilṭ al-Aswad
native_term:
طلخ /ءادوس طلخ / ءادوس
/ءادوس ہرّ م /یوادوس
دوسلاا طلخلا

description:
One of the four humours, which is a sediment of
normal sanguine with a taste between
sweetness and astringency

Black bile produced either by combustion of
black bile itself or combustion of any of the other
three humours, i.e., sanguine, phlegm,
yellow bile

One of the abnormal types of black bile,
produced by combustion of sanguine

One of the abnormal types of black bile,
produced by combustion of yellow bile

One of the abnormal types of black bile,
produced by combustion of phlegm

One of the abnormal types of black bile,
produced by combustion of black bile itself

Parts of the body formed of normal humours
that retain their own shapes

Organs whose visible parts have the same
name and definitions as the whole organ
transliteration:
A‘ḍā’
Mufrada / A‘ḍā’ Basīṭa /
A‘ḍā’
Mutashābiha al-Ajzā’
native_term:
ءاضعا / ہدرفم ءاضعا
ۃھباشتم ءاضعا /ہطیسب
ءازجلاا

description: Hard and white simple organ forming skeleton

Simple organ, which is softer than bone but
relatively harder than other tissues

White and elastic simple organ originating from
brain and the spinal cord

Simple organ bearing resemblance to nerve,
which arises from the ends of muscle and gets
attached to the mobile parts of the body

White simple organ bearing resemblance to
nerve, strengthening the joint by joining one
bone with another

Simple long hollow pulsating organ originating
from heart, which contracts and expands with a
period of rest in between the two movements

Simple non-pulsating organ similar to artery,
originating from liver

Simple organ made of invisible nerve-like fibres,
which is spread into thin sheets over
various organs

Simple organ that fills spaces between other
simple organs

White and soft simple organ having oily matter,
which is commonly found over membranes

Simple organ originating from thicker part of
body vapours that keeps on accumulating into
the skin pores and gets transformed into hair; it
grows in length during whole lifetime of a person

Simple organ which always grows in length
during whole lifetime of a person and remains
attached with distal phalanx

Simple organ which forms outer
covering of body

Organs whose comprising parts, irrespective of
size, differ in nature as well as name from the
whole organ, e.g., hand, face, etc., where a part
of the face cannot be called the face and a part
of hand cannot be called the hand

Compound organs composed of only simple
organs, e.g., muscle which is composed of
flesh, fat, etc.
native_term:
بیکرت ہب ہبکرم ءاضعا
یلوّ ا

description:
Compound organs composed of a compound
organ type I with other organs, e.g., eye which is
composed of muscle (a compound organ type I),
fluids and seven layers

Compound organs composed of a compound
organ type II with other organs, e.g., face which
is composed of eye (a compound organ type II),
nose, mouth, cheeks, etc.

Compound organs composed of a compound
organ type III with other organs, e.g., head
which is composed of face (a compound organ
type III), ear, brain, etc.

english_term:
organs for nutrition,
growth and reproduction
description:
Organs executing the functions of the physical
faculty, with the liver being the chief organ

Organs making suitable changes in the diet
consumed by an individual, to make it part of his
body and replace wear and tear

Organs executing functions of reproductive
faculty for preservation of species, the testes
being the chief organ in males and the ovaries
in females

english_term:
organs for blood
circulation and
respiration
description:
Organs executing functions of vital faculty, the
heart being the chief organ

Organs executing the functions of the psychic
faculty, the brain being the chief organ

Light gaseous substance obtained from the
interaction of inspired air with subtle humours
found in organs and fluids of the body and help
faculties in their functions; the term does not
cover Rūḥ mentioned under Unani pharmacy

The pneuma found in the organs of the psychic
faculty whose centre is brain and helps psychic
faculty to perform its functions

The pneuma found in the organs of the vital
faculty whose centre is heart and helps vital
faculty to perform its functions

The pneuma found in the organs of the physical
faculty whose centre is liver and helps physical
faculty to perform its functions

One of the seven factors of existence, which
provides the basis for different bodily functions

Faculty serving the functions of nutrition, growth,
reproduction and evacuation of waste products
from the body for the preservation of the
individual as well as the species

Physical faculties responsible for preservation of
the individual as well as the species

Primary physical faculty making alteration in the
food for the preservation of the individual

One of the type of physical faculties making
alteration in the food in such a manner that it
becomes temperamentally similar to the body
and suitable to replace daily wear and tear

One of the three components of nutritive faculty,
which selects and collects the matter
for digestion

One of the three components of the nutritive
faculty, which attaches
digested matter to the organs for their nutrition

One of the three components of the nutritive
faculty, which transforms the matter attached to
the organ by the adhesive faculty in such a way
that it resembles the nourished organ in all
respects and becomes a part of that organ

One of the physical faculties, which develops
the organs in the required form and size and
integrates the nutrient material to complete
individual development

Primary physical faculties provided to an
individual for preservation of its species

One of the reproductive faculties, which forms
the male and female reproductive units

Faculty in the male element separating various
faculties in the sperm and rearranging them to
provide each member the temperament
appropriate for it

One of the reproductive faculties, which gives
shape to each organ of body in accordance with
the species or race

Faculties that help in the actions of
nutritive faculty

Faculty which serves the nutritive faculty and
absorbs beneficial material into the body

Faculty which serves the nutritive faculty and
retains the dietary material until the digestive
faculty completes its work

Faculty which serves the nutritive faculty and
digests the dietary material to make it part
of an organ

Faculty which serves the nutritive faculty and
expels waste products from body

Faculty which is essential for life and reaches
from heart to body organs through arteries and
keeps them alive

Faculty which is furnished in an individual for
sensory/perceptive and motor/motive function of
the body; it controls nervous tissues to perform
the functions of sensation/perception and
regulates the nervous system for motor activity

Type of psychic and mental faculty which
regulates motor activities in the body; the motor
faculty contracts and relaxes the tendons,
through which the organs and the joints
extend and flex

One of the motor faculties that prepares the
mind to do something either in favour or
against the will
transliteration:
Quwwat Shawqiyya /
Quwwat Nuzū‘iyya/
Quwwat Isti‘dādiyya

description:
A subserving faculty of the motivating faculty,
which directs the mind to obtain things
perceived to be useful

A subserving faculty of the motivating faculty,
which directs the mind for a reaction against a
threat or an event comprehended to be harmful

One of the motor faculties, which helps in
directing the organs for actions

english_term:
receptive faculty/
sensory faculty/
perceptive power
description:
Type of psychic faculty which regulates sensory/
perceptive functions of body
native_term:
توق / ہکردم توق
ہیسّ ح توق /کاردا

description:
One of the sensory faculties, which help to
interpret the outer sensations of the body

Five external senses, executed by external
sense organs, i.e., eye, ear, nose,
tongue and skin

Capability of eyes to focus and detect images/
power which performs the functions of vision

Power/sense which perceives sounds and
performs the function of hearing
Power/sense which perceives odours
Sense/capability to detect different tastes
Power which perceives sensation of touch

One of the sensory faculties, which recognises,
receives and collects the sensations forwarded
by external senses; this faculty has its centre/
seat inside the brain

One of the five internal perceptive faculties,
which receives all sensations, composes them
into percepts and enables proper sensory
appreciations

One of the five internal perceptive faculties,
which preserves knowledge perceived by the
faculty of composite sense and the knowledge
or sense with which new sensory experiences of
the same or similar types can be compared

One of the five internal perceptive faculties,
which interprets the meanings of those
particular forms perceived by faculty of
composite sense and decides what is in favour
of an individual and what is against him or her

english_term:
faculty of memory /
cognitive faculty/
memorizing power
description:
One of the five internal perceptive faculties,
which preserves the meanings derived by the
faculty of imagination with interpretation; the
memory may be instantaneous, short-term

hotness, coldness, dryness and wetness/
moistness takes place
When heat dominates abnormally in the body
When cold dominates abnormally in the body

When wetness dominates abnormally
in the body

When dryness dominates abnormally
in the body

Morbid temperament in which change in four
physical properties, i.e., hotness, coldness,
dryness and wetness/moistness takes place
with the involvement of substance

Morbid temperament in which change in any
one of four physical properties, i.e., hotness,
coldness, dryness and wetness/moistness takes
place with the involvement of substance

Morbid hot temperament caused by the
predominance of hot substance

Morbid cold temperament caused by the
predominance of cold substance

Morbid moist temperament caused by the
predominance of moist substance

Morbid dry temperament caused by the
predominance of dry substance

The compound morbid temperament which
occurs when any two (one active and one
passive) of the four physical properties, i.e.,
hotness, coldness, dryness and moistness
dominate abnormally over the others

The compound morbid temperament which
occurs when any two (one active and one
passive) of the four physical properties, i.e.,
hotness, coldness, dryness and moistness
dominate abnormally over the others without
involving substance

english_term:
simple morbid hot and
wet temperament
description:
Morbid hot and wet temperament caused by
only predominance of hot and wet temperament
without involving substance

english_term:
simple morbid hot and
dry temperament
description:
Morbid hot and dry temperament caused by only
predominance of hot and dry temperament
without involving substance

english_term:
simple morbid cold and
moist temperament
description:
Morbid cold and moist temperament caused by
only predominance of cold and wet
temperament without involving substance

english_term:
simple cold and dry
morbid temperament
description:
Morbid cold and dry temperament caused by
only predominance of cold and dry temperament
without involving substance

Compound morbid temperament which occurs
when any two (one active and one passive) of
the four physical properties, i.e., hot, cold, dry
and moist, dominate abnormally over the others
due to the predominance of substance

english_term:
morbid hot and moist
temperament with
substance
description:
Morbid hot and moist temperament associated
with predominance of hot and wet substances

english_term:
morbid hot and dry
temperament associated
with substance
description:
Morbid hot and dry temperament associated
with predominance of hot and dry substances

english_term:
morbid cold and moist
temperament with
substance
description:
Morbid cold and moist temperament associated
with predominance of cold and wet substances

english_term:
morbid cold and dry
temperament asso-
ciated with substance
description:
Morbid cold and dry temperament associated
with predominance of cold and dry substances

english_term:
stable morbid tempera-
ment / constant
intemperament
description:
Morbid temperament, which continues in a
steady mode and does not get corrected easily

Morbid temperament, which does not continue
in a steady mode and gets corrected easily
Morbid temperament which persists indefinitely

When any of four humours exceeds
quantitatively or qualitatively

Quantitative increase in volume of sanguine
humour exerting pressure on the vessels that
may lead to heaviness in the body in general
and eyes, head and temporal region in particular
and may also lead to bleeding due to rupture of
delicate vessels

Qualitative imperfection or quantitative excess
of bilious humour in the body characterized by
rapid and swift pulse, urine that is flame yellow
and of thin consistency, increased thirst,
dryness and roughness of tongue and bitter
taste, yellowish discolouration of skin and
eyes, etc.

Qualitative imperfection or quantitative excess
of phlegmatic humour in the body characterized
by sluggishness, soft skin, excessive secretion
of sticky saliva, delayed digestion, increase in
sleep, slow pulse, etc.

Qualitative imperfection or quantitative excess
of melancholic humour characterized by rough,
dry and dark skin, increased appetite, increased
viscosity of blood, dark coloured/blackish urine,
tendency to develop splenic diseases and
psychiatric disorders

Diseases which arise due to the abnormal
quantity or quality of sanguine humour; these
diseases are considered to be of hot and moist
temperament

Diseases which arise due to the abnormal
quantity or quality of bilious humour; these
diseases are considered to be of hot and dry
temperament

Diseases which arise due to the abnormal
quantity or quality of phlegmatic humour; these
diseases are considered to be of cold and moist
temperament

Diseases which arise due to the abnormal
quantity or quality of melancholic humour; these
diseases are considered to be of cold and dry
temperament

Diseases in which the original shape of an
organ is changed

One of the types of disease of constitution
involving particularly morphological alterations
in the compound organs

One of the types of disease of constitution
specific to tracts/ tubular structures such as
vessels, ducts, etc.; in these conditions the
lumen may become dilated, narrowed or
completely blocked

One of the types of disease of constitution seen
in hollow organs leading to either abnormal
narrowing or dilatation; includes increase,
decrease, occlusion or emptiness
Dilatation of vasa/cavity
Narrowing of vasa/cavity

Vasa/ cavity becoming obstructed or repleted,
e.g., obstruction of ventricles of brain
in apoplexy
Depletion of vasa/cavity

english_term:
diseases of surface
of the organs
description:
One of the types of disease of constitution
associated with alterations in surface of viscera/
organ causing compromised physiological
functions, e.g., a viscera originally having
smooth surface becomes rough/puckered
and vice versa

Roughness of a surface which should be
smooth, e.g., roughness of the internal surface
of the trachea

Smoothness of a surface which should be
rough, e.g., smoothness of the internal surface
of the stomach

One of the types of disease of constitution
concerning pathological changes in the size /
weight of body viscera/organs; all kinds of
hypertrophies or atrophies are in this category

Increase in the size of an organ, e.g.,
elephantiasis

Generalized/as a whole increase in
size, e.g., obesity

Localized increase in size/increase in size of
part/organ of the body, e.g., hepatomegaly,
splenomegaly, etc.

Generalized / as a whole decrease in
size, e.g., emaciation

Localized decrease in size / decrease in the size
of part of the body e.g., shrinkage of
organ / atrophy

Diseases affecting the numbers of organs of the
body; one of the types of disease of constitution
which is associated with congenital or acquired
numeral abnormality of viscera or body organs

Increase in number of organs; increase in
number of body parts, e.g., appearance of extra
teeth and fingers

english_term:
nonpathological increase
in number of body parts
description:
Congenital increase in number of parts of the
body, e.g., additional teeth or additional fingers

english_term:
abnormal or pathological
increase in number
description:
Acquired pathological increase in parts of the
body, e.g., tumour

Decrease in number of body parts, e.g.,
presence of one kidney instead of two

Congenital decrease in number of body parts,
e.g., congenital absence of one finger

Acquired decrease in number of parts of the
body, e.g., accidental loss of one finger

One of the types of disease of constitution in
which defects in position and proximity of body
organs occur; the defects in position include
total or partial shifting of any organ; also
included are defects in voluntary and involuntary
movements of body organs; the movement may
decrease or increase; defects in proximity
include loss of gap between two adjacent
organs leading to cessation of their movement

There are four types of disease related to
position: 1. total shifting of an organ from its
position; 2. partial shifting of an organ, as in
hernia; 3. involuntary abnormal increased
movement of an organ as in tremors;
4. decreased movement of a movable organ,
as in stiffness of a joint

Complete displacement of a body part, as with
joint displacement; when the head of the bone
completely subluxates from its normal position

Incomplete displacement or displacement of
part of an organ, as in intestinal hernia

Abnormal (sometimes involuntary) movement of
an organ, as with tremors

Fixity of an organ to its location, as with
calcification of joints in gout

The disease of an organ that arises due to its
association with another organ

Restriction of movement of an organ that was
previously moveable
Painful or difficult movement

Loss of continuity of any organ or part
of the body

Loss of continuity of skin caused by a sharp-
pointed object

1. Loss of continuity of skin due to excoriation/
scraping. 2. Sometimes refers to scraping of
internal lining of intestines
Loss of continuity of tissue without suppuration

Loss of continuity of tissue with suppuration; this
term does not cover Qarḥa mentioned
under diseases

description: Longitudinal loss of continuity of bone
Longitudinal minimal loss of continuity of nerve
Longitudinal loss of continuity of muscle

Loss of continuity of muscle at its end
Transverse loss of continuity of muscle
Loss of continuity of vein
Sudden break in continuity of a body part
Loss of continuity of an artery

simple disease, i.e., abnormal temperament,

involved in the causation of a single disease,
e.g., inflammation

A kind of compound disease/pathology
comprising abnormal temperament, abnormal
composition and loss of continuity

Inflammatory swellings which are hot in nature;
arising from blood, yellow bile and other
substances which as such are hot or become
hot due to putrefaction (putrefaction may be
interpreted as infection in present terms)

Inflammatory swellings which are not hot in

Sanguineous inflammation caused by qualitative
or quantitative predominance of
sanguine humour

Bilious inflammation caused by qualitative or
quantitative predominance of bile humour
Soft welling/oedema is usually phlegmatic

Soft tumours which are usually phlegmatic but
distinguished by their sac

An oedematous swelling where the air is
mixed with fluid

Accumulation of air in a hollow organ but not
admixed with the organ and remaining discrete
from the tissue, leading to distension
and tumescence

Diseases with severe signs and symptoms,
commonly reaching their peak on the fourth day;
their signs and symptoms are severe but do not
last more than twenty days

Diseases which have a slow onset, longer
duration and lesser severity and reach their
peak after a long time

Diseases which appear externally on the body
and can be diagnosed commonly by general
physical examination, e.g., diseases of skin,
nails, hair, etc.

Diseases not evident externally, occurring inside
the body; such diseases cannot be diagnosed

Diseases associated with particular organs, e.g.,
blindness (eyes) and deafness (ears)

Disease of an organ due to disease of another,
interconnected organ; one organ shares the
disease with another, because of the
interconnection, e.g., the brain and stomach are

Infectious diseases that transmit from one
person to another; some of the diseases are
infectious, such as leprosy, scabies, smallpox,
epidemic fever, and putrid ulcer; they commonly
occur when houses are congested and the
neighbouring area is low-lying

Diseases continuing from one
generation to another

Diseases which are peculiar to a race, tribe or
people of a region; this term does not cover

stages/phases of a disease in its due course

The stage during which a disease manifests

Stage of advancement / time of increase of a

english_term:
stadium acmes /
height of malady / period

description:
Stage of culmination/peak of a disease; the

Stage of decline of a disease; stage at which
signs and symptoms of illness start to decline

Shifting of morbid matter from the site of

The knowledge of signs and symptoms of health
and diseases

Clinical feature of a disease which indicates its
present condition

Symptoms reminiscent of previous disease or
symptoms of the disease showing previous
condition of the disease; inference drawn by the
physician from the existing signs and symptoms
of the patient about previous disease condition
helps the physician in arriving at correct
diagnosis; it also indicates the authority of the
physician on the subject matter and his clinical
practices, and increases the confidence of the
patient in the physician

Symptoms of the disease indicating its future
condition; this helps the patient and the
physician to adopt preventive measures and
develops the confidence of the patient in the
clinical expertise of the physician

Signs and symptoms of health include normal
temperament, form, position, quantity and
number of an organ and signs and symptoms of
normal functions of every organ

Signs and symptoms related to disease may be
characteristic features of a particular disease or
may indicate the location or cause of
